* Phases and phase transitions
Phase equilibrium, Gibbs rules, chemical equilibrium. Liquid-gas system, Clausius-Clapeyron equation, latent heat, van der Waals equation and Maxwell construction. Continuous phase transitions and critical phenomena.

* The third law of thermodynamics
Planck's and Nernst's formulations, main consequences.

* Mathematical statistics and probability theory
Probability, stochastic variables, distribution function (binomial, Poisson, Gaussian distributions), the law of large numbers, central limit theorem.

* Basic theoretical concepts of statistical physics
Phase space, phase volume, microscopic and macroscopic states, statistical description, Liouville theorem. Boltzmann entropy.

* Principles of statistical description of thermodynamic processes
The principle of equal probability, microcanonical ensemble. Interaction of the system with a thermal bath, canonical and great canonical statistical ensemble, fluctuations of thermodynamic quantities. Gibbs entropy. Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution."}

NAME: xAct: tensor analysis by computer 1
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"It will be explained how tensor analysis can be carried out efficiently within Mathematica/Wolfram Language using 
xAct system. The applications are mostly tailored for Theoretical Physics and General Relativity but other 
applications to mechanics of continuous media are also possible. 
"}
E: {"TITLE":"terms of passing the course","MEMO":"Assignments made by the student during the course.\r\n"}
L:
{"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"A. García-Parrado, J.M.Martín-García: Spinors: A Mathematica package for doing spinor calculus in General Relativity. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2012.04.024
R. Maeder: Computer Science with Mathematica, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge (2000).
J. M. Martín-García: xAct: Efficient tensor computer algebra for the Wolfram Language http://www.xact.es
J.M.Martín-García: xPerm: fast index canonicalization for tensor computer algebra. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2008.05.009
"}
P: {"TITLE":"requirements for assessment of study","MEMO":"Assignments made by the student during the course.\r\n"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"Lecture 1. General description of xAct and some selected examples.
Lecture 2. Introduction to the Wolfram Language.
Lecture 3. xTensor and its data types: working with tensors and covariant derivatives. Canonicalization of tensorial expressions.
Lecture 4. Working with a single and multiple metric tensors. Canonicalization of expressions with a metric tensor.
Lecture 5. Canonicalization of expressions with covariant derivatives. Pattern indices.
Lecture 6. Implementation of general tensorial rules.
Lecture 7. Constant symbols, inert heads, parameters and scalar functions. Lie brackets and vector contraction of tensor slots.
Lecture 8. The variational derivative. Working examples with the Einstein-Hilbert action (Palatini formalism), f(R) theory and Lovelock gravity.
Lecture 9. The 1+3 decomposition. ADM formalism.
Lecture 10. Main differential identities of a Killing vector. The Mars-Simon tensor in vacuum.
Lecture 11. The conformal equations.
Lecture 12. Component computations with xCoba. Storage of components: the tensor values framework and the CTensor container.
Lecture 13. The containers CTensor and CCovD and their converters. The xCoba cache system.
Lecture 14. Curvature computations with xCoba. 

See 

     http://www.xact.es/xActCourse_Prague/ 

for additional course details.

Some practical details about the course (schedule, etc) will be supplied during the meeting with students (Setkání se studenty) on Tuesday 8th October at 10:40.
See 

http://utf.mff.cuni.cz/seminare/semmf.pl

"}

NAME: Special Workshop of the Institute of Theoretical Physics
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"A two-day lecture camp with a scientific and social program. Lectures for both advanced bachelor's students and \r\nstudents of the master's and doctoral program in theoretical physics.\r\n"}
E: {"TITLE":"terms of passing the course","MEMO":"The credit is granted based on the participation in the ITP workshop. To participate in the workshop, you need to register. Details regarding the registration are available on the workshop page (link above). Enrollment without a valid registration will be canceled."}

NAME: Foundations of Numerical Study of Spacetimes
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Basic numerical methods for solving Einstein equations of general relativity. For the 4th and 5th year of TF study.\r\n"}
L:
{"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"M. Alcubierre, Introduction to 3+1 numerical relativity, Oxford 2012.
T. W. Baumgarte, S. L. Shapiro, Numerical Relativity: Solving Einstein's Equations on the Computer, Cambridge 2010.
J. Fraudiener et al (eds.), Analytical and numerical approaches to mathematical relativity, Springer 2006.
"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"* Stationary spacetimes
Elliptical PDE with a free boundary condition, rotating relativistic polytropy.

* 3 + 1 formulation of the Einstein equations
The most important variants, mathematical requirements for systems of hyperbolic PDE, initial data for numerical relativity, the boundary conditions.

* Critical phenomena in gravitational collapse
Spherically symmetric gravitational collapse, choice of coordinates, numerical methods for the study of the critical behavior.

* Black-hole numerical spacetimes
Representation of black holes in the initial data and during the simulation, interpretation of the results of numerical simulations, black hole horizons, emitted gravitational waves.
"}

NAME: Winter Training Course
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Winter selective training course. Subject is for students who completed their study obligations with interest to 
continue to do sports with KTV MFF. Enrolling to subject is due to capacity limited. Students with subject in their 
curriculum have priority. The stay at courses is paid by students. The price depends on duration and destination. 
Price for course in Czechia is between 2200,- and 5500,-CZK. Abroad courses between 9000,- and 11000,-CZK. 
Students do not have to participate in any of these courses, but can participate repeatedly. Detail information at 
KTV websites.
"}

NAME: Optional Physical Education
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"This course is designed for students of both Czech and English programmes who are interested in participating 
in the sports classes of Department of Physical Education or training at the MFF College Sports Club 
(performance or competitive level). 
For students in the Czech programme, this is a physical education course beyond the mandatory four credits of 
physical education in the Bachelor's programme.
For students in the English programme, this is a recreational physical education course in a selected group of 
sports listed at https://ktv.mff.cuni.cz/en/courses/.  
This course may be taken
"}

NAME: Physical Education I
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Physical education is required during bachelor studies. First year students generally register for these courses in 
the winter semester in accordance with their recommended course of study. In place of one of the recommended 
courses NTVY0014, NTVY015, NTVY016 and NTVY017 it is possible to enrol in the summer training course 
NTVY018 or the winter training course NTVY019. 
Students can enrol in this course at any time during their bachelor studies. 
Students of MFF who have a course listed in their recommended study plan are given priority during registration.
"}

NAME: Summer Training
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Summer training course. It focuses on sports games, water sports, mountain biking and various outdoor sports. 
Students can enrol in this course at any time during their bachelor studies and can earn their required 4th credit.
Enrolment for these courses is limited. Students of MFF who have a course listed in their recommended study plan 
are given priority during registration.
"}

NAME: Winter Training
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Winter training course. It focuses on the downhill, cross-country skiing and snowboarding. Students can enrol in 
this course at any time during bachelor studies and thus can obtain the required 4th credit.

Enrolment for these courses is limited. Students of MFF who have a course listed in their recommended study plan 
are given priority during registration.
"}

NAME: Practical Course in Physics I for Secondary School Teaching
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"Measuring of the gravity acceleration 
Study of harmonic oscillation of mechanic oscillator
Study of oscillation of coupled pendula
Study of rigid body rotation 
Measurement of inertia of wheel
Measurement of tensile modulus
Test of dynamic deformation in press
Free fall of sphere in viscous liquid
Measurement of viscosity
Study of flow of viscous liquid in tubes 
Dependence of surface tension on concentration of surface-active agent
Study of temperature dependence of surface tension
Study of Brown's motion
Velocity of sound
Calibration of resistance thermometer and thermocouple - phase transitions
"}

NAME: Selected Topics on Physics III
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Four selected laboratory tasks introduce in experimental work 
(physics of metals, semiconductors, nuclear physics and electronics).
For students of the fourth grade (teachers of physics for primary school).

"}
S: {"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"The aim of this subject is to introduce students to the work of experimental physicists. Students participated on some experiments carried on in various laboratories of MFF UK. \r\n \r\n"}

NAME: Propaedeutics of Physical Experiments I
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Optional practical education. Students perform simple and computer controlled experiments. These experiments supplement and extend the introductory lecture of physics and complement missing experimental skills. \r\nScheduled for grade 1 teachers education of mathematics and physics at secondary\/primary schools."}

NAME: Practical Course in Multimedia Technology
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"The course is focused on practical skills with classical audio, video and photo technology and computer technology.\r\n\r\n"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"The seminar is aimed at students of pedagogical specialization, 1st. ? 10th. semester. It consists of six lectures and six practical tasks performed individually by the students.

The lectures:

These lessons are managed in similar way as commercial software training courses. Due to the lack of time, they are aimed at the basics of work in programs mentioned below. Students perform simple tasks under the guidance of the teacher, after the end they elaborate a "miniproject" based on the gained knowledge.

1.	Corel Draw - the vector-graphics editor (2 lectures)
2.	Corel Photopaint - the bitmap editor
3.	The basics of html (2 lectures)
4.	ISES - The school experimental system

The individual tasks

1.	Recording and editing audio
2.	Recording and editing video
3.	Performing a computer upgrade
4.	Connecting to the internet
5.	Useful freeware I - The internet
6.	Useful freeware II - Office software, system tools, graphics
"}

NAME: Social Skills and Work II
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"This course is aimed on practical training of communication skills applicable in dialogue, group leadership and 
conflict resolution. Emphasis is on awareness of aims and priorities, empathy and looking for a solution which 
satisfies all the parties involved (win-win strategy). Practical training of stress management is also a part of the 
course. 
"}
E: {"TITLE":"terms of passing the course","MEMO":"Credits are given for active participation at the seminar."}
L:
{"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"Gillernová, I., Krejèová, L. Sociální dovednosti ve škole. Grada, Praha 2012. 
Plamínek, J. Komunikace a prezentace. Grada, Praha 2012
Rosenberg, M. Nenásilná komunikace. Portál, Praha 2013. 
Thun von, R. Jak spolu komunikujeme?. Grada, Praha 2005. 
"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"Basics of communication (physical proximity, voice, gestures, eye contact)
Mindfulness in communication (awareness of aims and priorities, awareness of emotions, stress management, empathy)
Presentation (prepared and improvised presentation, feedback)
Group leadership (group types, leadership styles)
Group dynamics (phases of group development, trust in group, roles in group)
Inter-vision methods for burnout prevention (Bálint groups)
Conflict resolution and mediation (self-awareness, empathy to the other, clear and concrete expression, looking for mutually satisfactory solution)

"}

NAME: Physics Teaching Propedeutics II
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"The seminar follows the seminar NUFY 115; it is aimed at finding and solving problems teaches meet in their 
everyday practice (the work of a class teacher, chances and risks of modern technologies in physics teaching and 
learning, learning styles, especially in connection with physics, how to write educational documentation, how to 
cooperate with parents, etc.) - again starting not from theoretical knowledge of pedagogy and psychology but from 
concrete experience of the teacher. Students attending the seminar are guided to discuss presented problems and 
expected to participate actively at the 
"}
L: {"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"Fenclov\u00e1, J.: Didaktick\u00e9 my\u0161len\u00ed a jedn\u00e1n\u00ed u\u010ditele fyziky. SPN Praha, 1984 Bartu\u0161ka, K.: Sb\u00edrka \u0159e\u0161en\u00fdch \u00faloh z fyziky I- IV. Prometheus Praha, 1997, 1998, 2000 Nahodil, J.: Fyzika v b\u011b\u017en\u00e9m \u017eivot\u011b. Prometheus Praha, 1996 U\u010debnice fyziky pro st\u0159edn\u00ed \u0161koly \r\n"}
S: {"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"Class teacher's work. Class documentation. Troubleshooting educational and educational issues. Collaboration with parents. Out-of-school activities. How to protect yourself in case of problems, burnout syndrome.\r\n\r\n"}

NAME: Quantitative physics tasks
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"The seminar is focused on activities improving selected skills needed for solving quantitative physics tasks. The \r\napplicability of the activities in high school classes will be discussed during the seminar.\r\n"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"The seminar will focus on various aspects of problem solving in physics, e.g.:
Creation of problem solving plan
Careful reading of the tasks
Qualitative analysis of physics problems
Classification and description of physics equations
Solving aloud
Assessment of the reasonableness of the answers
"}

NAME: Programming III
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Fundamentals of C\/C++ programming languages and programming environment of the UNIX operating system.  The course is designed primarily for students prepared for elementary and secondary school teaching and it is taught last time this academic year.\r\n  \r\n"}

NAME: Operating Systems and System Software
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Operating system, what is it, its parts and their programming. Compiler and its programming. The course is taught last time this academic year.\r\n  \r\n"}

NAME: Algebra
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Basics of the theory of groups, rings and modules. Polynomial rings. Theory of fields. \r\n\r\n"}

NAME: Mathematical Analysis Applications in Secondary School Mathematics
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Connections between university and high school mathematics courses."}

NAME: Development of Mathematics Education
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"The course is open to all students (future teachers) who are interested in the development of mathematical education and teaching throughout the ages. The interesting mathematical problems which emerged in the last time will be showed and solved.\r\n\r\n"}
L:
{"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"Literature is only in Czech.

J. Bečvář a kol.: Matematika ve středověké Evropě, edice Dějiny matematiky, sv. č. 19, Praha, 2001.

J. Bečvář, M. Bečvářová, H. Vymazalová: Matematiky ve středověku. Egypt a Mezopotámie, edice Dějiny matematiky, sv. č. 23, Praha, 2003. 

O. Chlup: Výchova v zrcadle pramenů, Praha, 1948.

O. Kádner: Vývoj a dnešní soustava školství, Praha, 1929, 1931, 1933, 1938. 

Z. Veselá: Dokumenty z vývoje české střední školy  1849-1939, Praha, 1973.

Časopis pro pěstování mathematiky a fysiky, výroční zprávy gymnázií, reálek, odborných škol, učitelských ústavů, archívní materiály apod.
"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"Teaching of mathematics and the development of mathematical thinking in the Ancienit (schools, mathematics in the systems of education).

The position of mathematics in the system of education in the Modele Agens (elementary schools, universities).

Mathematics in the Renaissance and "New Age" (national mathematical textbooks, kinds of schools, special education for technics and clerks).

Jesuit's schools (elementary, secondary and high schools, universities) and the role of mathematics in their system of education.

The bird of the technical schools (polytechnics, "real" schools, mathematics and descriptive geometry in the preparation of future technics).

The education in the Czech lands in the 19th century (three levels of education, leaving examinations, preparation of future teachers for secondary schools, special courses for teachers from elementary schools, so called "teacher's examinations", entrance examinations).

"}

NAME: History of Mathematics in Antiquity
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Optional lectures for students - future teachers. The lectures are devoted to the development of mathematics in the Ancient civilizations."}
C: {"TITLE":"aim of subject","MEMO":"This course helps to obtain theoretical background for teaching mathematics at high school.\r\n"}
L:
{"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"M. Kline:  Mathematical Thought from Ancient to Modern Times. Oxford Univ. Press, New York 1990.
R. Cooke:  The History of Mathematics, A Brief Course. Wiley, New York 1997.
J. Stillwell:  Mathematics and Its History. Springer-Verlag, New York 1994.
W. S. Anglin:  Mathematics - A Concise History and Philosophy. Springer-Verlag, New York 1994.
W. S. Anglin, J. Lambek:  The Heritage of Thales. Springer-Verlag, New York 1995.
H. Gericke:  Mathematik in Antik, Orient und Abendland. FourierVerlag, Wiesbaden 2003.
J. Bečvář, M. Bečvářová, H. Vymazalová: Matematika ve starověku. Egypt a Mezopotámie. Praha 2003.
"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"1. Mathematics in ancient Egypt. Writing and counting. Number system. Arithmetics. Geometry. Algebra. Mathematical problems from daily life.

2. Mathematics in Mesopotamia. Writing and counting. Number system. Arithmetics. Geometry. Algebra. Birth of the theoretical mathematics. Mathematical problems from daily life.

3. Chinese mathematics in the ancient time. Basic information.

4. Mathematics of the Hindus. Basic information.
"}

NAME: Methods of Solving Mathematical Problems II
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"Countable and uncountable sets, properties of the set or real numbers. Elementary functions and their graphs, solution of 
equations and inequalities (included graphical solution) and their systems. Basic princips of combinatorics and solutions of 
combinatorics problems.
"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"1. Elementary geometric problems - sets of points with given properties, geometric construction in plane, applications of congruent planar transformation. 

2. Surfaces of planar figures, volumes of solids. Developments of solids, intersection with a plane. Principle of Cavalieri and Guldin. 

3. Basic notions of graph theory, applications to problem solution. Connection of the graph theory to spatial geometry. 

4. Combinatorical problems. 

"}

NAME: Seminar on Computational Aspects of Optimisation
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"A seminar devoted to the work in computer laboratory and using software \r\nfor calculations in optimization.\r\n"}

NAME: Seminar on computer typography
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"We describe the METAFONT\/METAPOST language and its philosophy.\r\n"}
S:
{"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"Historical notes about TeX fonts, standard TeX bitmap fonts source codes structure

Comparision of METAFONT and METAPOST

How the assignment and equation using linear dependences differ

Language nonprocedurality - for cycles inside a single statement

Definitions with typed arguments - subroutine replacement

Example of "subroutine" converting 2D <-> 3D coordinates, where "conversion direction" depends on which coordinates are known

Working with bitmaps (inner representation), hachuring techniques in METAFONT, comparing with METAPOST

Programs for ligatures and kernings (TFM)

Including texts in drawings (cooperation of METAPOST and TeX)

Comparing methods incorporating pictures in TeX and pdfTeX
"}

NAME: Research Seminar for the Focus "InfKomm"
L: {"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"Will be announced at the beginning of the lecture.\r\n"}

NAME: Introduction to Deep Learning
A:
{"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"University of Passau - Code: 471616;
Lecturer: Lemmerich;
Course content:
Basics of Representation Learning.
Perceptron Learning.
Feedforward Neural Networks.
Gradient Descent and Backpropagation.
Regularization in Deep Learning.
Convolutional Neural Networks.
Recurrent Neural Networks.
Autoencoders.
Adversarial Training.
Graph Neural Networks.
Applications of Deep Learning for Text, Sequences, and Images.
Explainability and Deep Learning.
"}

NAME: Computational Complexity Theory
L: {"TITLE":"literature","MEMO":"Arora, Barak, Computational Complexity: A Modern Approach, Cambridge University Press, 2009.;\r\nPapadimitriou, Computational Complexity, Addison-Wesley, 1995.\t\r\n"}

NAME: Selected Topics on Mathematics
A: {"TITLE":"annotation","MEMO":"The course will be a continuation of the basic course Mathematics for chemists I, II (S710P04A, S710P04B). It's aim is to present some of such parts of mathematical analysis and algebra which form the useful tool for chemists and could not be included into the basic course."}
S: {"TITLE":"syllabus","MEMO":"Basic notions of vector and tensor theory, vector and tensor algebra and calculus; surface integral; Green's, Stokes's and Gauss's theorems; Fourier series, Fourier transform; introduction to functional analysis in Hilbet spaces; introduction to calculus of variation.\r\n"}
